title: Letters: Directors' duties are not a doddle
text:
Treasurer is aware of banks’ rate limitations

Treasurer Josh Frydenberg is only playing politics when he complains that Australian banks have not reduced the interest on their loans in step with the RBA’s recent reduction.

If the banks borrowed all the money they lent to borrowers from the RBA, and if the interest paid to the RBA changed every time a reduction was announced, then of course they would be able to reduce the interest they charged every time the RBA reduced interest rates.

But this is not how the system works. The money the banks borrow is not all secured at rates that go up or down in step with the RBA’s announcements. In particular, some of it is borrowed from overseas. The Treasurer knows this.

The banks should make this clear every time they make rate changes.

John Melville-Jones

Yanchep, WA

Spare some thought for ignored deposit-holders

It’s about time we stopped thinking that it is only those who are buying houses through debt who need our sympathy. In a table published yesterday (‘‘Morrison slams banks for not passing on cut’’), you showed that someone who took out a mortgage back in 2008 with the CBA has seen their interest rate cut by 7.14 percentage points. Assuming this person took out a mortgage of $300,000 in that year (the average price then for a house in Melbourne was $460,827), the annual cost of the interest has fallen by $21,400 – and all this in after-tax dollars. Not a bad pay rise over 11 years. And the average price of a Melbourne home is now almost double that of 2008, at $914,518. And that capital gain will be tax-free too.

On the other hand, savers in bank term deposits have been crucified; not that we read much about their plight. Perhaps your paper could look into that.

Anthony Baird

Brighton East, Vic

RBA should be realistic about jobless numbers

The key reasons given for the interest rate cut are to kickstart the economy, reduce unemployment to about 4.5per cent and get inflation up to 2-3 per cent. However, there is nothing much the RBA can do to reduce the unemployment figure of ‘‘officially’’ about 5.3 per cent unless it is honest and accepts that the real unemployment figure is 15 per cent plus 13 per cent underemployed, and has been for many years.

We would have to have another Industrial Revolution to have any hope of getting to 4.5 per cent. The massive understatement of Australia’s monthly unemployment figures for so long has resulted in big distortions and wrong decisions being made by the RBA and governments.

Marcus L’Estrange

St Kilda West, Vic

Lower rates won’t do much to lift spending

The idea that cheap money provides an excellent underpinning for a modern economy is a form of madness. The RBA’s current strategy of lowering interest rates to almost nothing in an attempt to boost economic activity is clearly self-defeating.

Businesses and mortgage holders are unlikely to vigorously expand their spending or investment as interest rates fall from 1 to 0.75 per cent, especially as banks have been prudent enough to hold borrowing rates steady. However savers, who may live off interest income, are more likely to spend when interest rates are at least above the inflation rate. They are now cutting back spending as they are forced to eat into capital.

Bankers and the government need to re-imagine an economy that rewards savers, who actually provide funds that support investment.

Peter Strachan

Cottesloe, WA
